fact_list.fact_text: A thin layer of water forms on the road surface on rainy days.
Even good tyres may not have a good grip on the road.
As speed increases, surface water builds up under the vehicle’s tyres.
When surface water builds up under the tyres, the vehicle glides on the road surface, a phenomenon known as ‘Aquaplaning’.
Aquaplaning results in the loss of steering control and braking efficiency.
The faster the speed, the more difficult it is to control the vehicle.
To counter aquaplaning, slow down by braking intermittently until control is regained.
When approaching a road that is flooded but passable, engage a lower gear to traverse the flood.
After passing through water, the brakes become ineffective.
To dry ineffective brakes after passing through water, pump the brake pedal repeatedly until braking action returns.
Brakes can also be dried by gently depressing the brake pedal with the left foot while pressing the accelerator with the right foot.
At night, the depth of flood water can be deceptive.
If uncertain about flood water depth, take an alternative route.
Stretches of open highways are usually subjected to strong winds.
To avoid being forced into the path of other traffic by strong winds, slow down and drive cautiously.
Too much or too little light affects our ability to see.
Sun-glare or light reflected off objects or pools of water on the road can dazzle and blind vision.
To counter sun-glare, wear sunglasses or lower the sun-visor.
Switch on your headlights from 7pm to 7am.
Drive at a slower speed at night than during the day.
